thread.title: Eichel scores a beauty but Sabres fall short
thread.title_full: Eichel scores a beauty but Sabres fall short

title: Eichel scores a beauty but Sabres fall short
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Eichel scores a beauty but Sabres fall short Jack Eichel, the wunderkind 18-year-old from Chelmsford, Massachusetts, by way of Boston University and a Hobey Baker Award, the No. 2 overall pick in last June's draft, made his Sabres' debut Thursday night. Post to Facebook Eichel scores a beauty but Sabres fall short Jack Eichel, the wunderkind 18-year-old from Chelmsford, Massachusetts, by way of Boston University and a Hobey Baker Award, the No. 2 overall pick in last June's draft, made his Sabres' debut Thursday night. Check out this story on WGRZ.com: http://on.wgrz.com/1Rx1Oda Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Eichel scores a beauty but Sabres fall short Leo Roth, Democrat & Chronicle 1:53 a.m. EDT October 9, 2015 Buffalo Sabres center Jack Eichel (15) celebrates after scoring his first NHL goal during the third period against the Ottawa Senators at First Niagara Center. Senators beat the Sabres 3-1. (Photo: Kevin Hoffman-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
BUFFALO, NY - OK, Buffalo Sabres fans, admit it. 
It was worth two years in hockey hell. Two years of watching your team finish in last place in the National Hockey League. Two years when you didn't have jack. 
But now you do have Jack. 
Jack Eichel, the wunderkind 18-year-old from Chelmsford, Massachusetts, by way of Boston University and a Hobey Baker Award, the No. 2 overall pick in last June's draft, made his Sabres' debut Thursday night. 
On the anticipation meter, only Gil Perreault's hello in 1970 (the franchise's first season) and Pierre Turgeon's in 1987 were the equal in Sabres' lore. That's because each was a No. 1 overall selection, and Eichel would have been had he not put on a pair of ice skates at the same time a kid named Connor McDavid did. One Buffalo Day Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 
PHOTO GALLERY: One Buffalo Day in Pegulaville 
Let's toss in the arrival of Santa Claus each year, too, because that's the kind of buzz that was generated inside First Niagara Center by a sellout crowd â€” with every 15th person (or so it seemed) wearing a No. 15 Eichel jersey. 
I'd like to report that Eichel scored on his first NHL shift, stirring memories of Danny Gare and Alex Molgilny at the old Aud. It actually took him a little more than 20 shifts to record his first goal, a beautiful top-shelf wrist shot on the power play that left enough time for the goaltender to blink once. 
Unfortunately for Eichel and the Sabres, they staggered through an offensively challenged first two periods, lost their starting goalie, Robin Lehner to a leg injury, had a goal by newcomer Evander Kane wiped away by the new coach's challenge rule (the play was offsides), and they fell to the Ottawa Senators 3-1.
